thread.title: Malcolm Turnbull claims credit for credit card interest rate cuts
thread.title_full: Malcolm Turnbull claims credit for credit card interest rate cuts

author: Adam Gartrell
title: Malcolm Turnbull claims credit for credit card interest rate cuts
text:
Opposition Leader Bill Shorten says the PM is desperate to avoid a banking royal commission. Photo: Andrew Meares 
He said even after ANZ's move, the big four banks did not have a single card in the top 20 of most competitive interest rates in Australia. They should drop their rates to "reasonable levels" below 10 per cent, he said. 
Independent senator Nick Xenophon said the banks were being irresponsible by leaving rates so high. 
"We are being gouged with credit cards and we actually need some fundamental reforms," he said. "We really need to look at greater market competition or the banks need to really explain themselves in why they are gouging consumers in this way." 
Government backbenchers are vowing to put further pressure on the banks with more public hearings due next month. 
Liberal MP and bank critic Scott Buchholz also believed the last round of hearings helped trigger ANZ's decision. 
"We will have the banks appearing in the next fortnight in Canberra, along with the Australian Banking Association, where I will continue to take a similar line of questioning with those banks that haven't taken the commercial choice to shift their interest rates yet," he said. Advertisement
